msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: Charles Albert Brougher served as Mississippi’s secretary of state in the 1860s. Born on June 19, 1824, in Morgan County, Alabama, Brougher moved to Mississippi at a young age, as his father entered politics there, serving in the Mississippi Senate in the early 1840s. Brougher graduated from Pennsylvania College (modern-day Gettysburg College) in 1846 and initially went into teaching. He then took up the study of law, and became a practicing attorney in Ripley, Mississippi in 1852.

In 1858, Brougher was elected Clerk of Mississippi’s House of Representatives. In 1860, he was appointed Mississippi’s secretary of state, to fill the vacancy created when B. R. Webb died in that office only six days into his first term. Brougher remained in that position through the secession crisis and first two years of the Civil War. He won reelection in 1863, and only left the secretary of state’s office when Union authorities took civil control of Mississippi in June 1865. Brougher was elected to the seat again in October 1865 and served until 1869. Brougher died on November 25, 1891. He was married to Marie Louise Earle and had seven children. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, December 3, 1891)
Cahrles Albert Brougher belonged to the following social groups:
Wiley Pope Harris was a U.S. congressman from Mississippi in the 1850s and a representative in the Confederate Congress.

Born in Pike County, Mississippi, on November 9, 1818, Harris attended the University of Virginia and then received a law degree from Transylvania College in Lexington, Kentucky. He began practicing law in 1840 in Gallatin, Mississippi, and within four years took a seat as circuit judge for the state’s second district. In 1850 Harris participated in Mississippi’s constitutional convention, and in 1852 was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives. He served one term and then returned to law practice in Jackson, Mississippi.

When Mississippi declared its separation from the Union in 1861 and joined the Confederacy, Harris secured a seat in the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States of America. Following the Civil War, he resumed practicing law. Harris died on December 3, 1891. He was married to Frances Mayes and had seven children. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
Wiley Pope Harris belonged to the following social groups:

Currently located in Lowndes County, Columbus was founded on December 6, 1819 in what was then a "non-county area." When Lowndes County was created on January 30, 1830, Columbus became its county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Rankin County, Brandon was incorporated on December 19, 1831 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: An organization that "send[s] and receiv[es] messages by electrical or radio signals, or the special equipment used for this purpose." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Telegraph Companies--New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company (Jackson, Miss.)

gloss.p: Located in Jackson, Mississippi, the South-Western Telegraph Company (also known as the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company) was established by an act of the legislature on February 3, 1860. The South-Western Telegraph Company was one of the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest and had many locations throughout that area. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)Located in Kentucky, the South-Western Telegraph Company (also known as the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company) was established by an act of the Mississippi State legislature on February 3, 1860. The South-Western Telegraph Company was one of the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest and had many locations throughout that area. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)Located in Louisville, Kentucky, New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees was a telegraph company established between 1857 and 1860. New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees were the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest. On February 3, 1860, the Mississippi State House amended the act which incorporated the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees, changing the company's name to Southwestern Telegraph Company. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)Located in Mobile, Alabama, the South-Western Telegraph Company (also known as the New Orleans & Ohio Telegraph Lessees and Southwestern Telegraph Company) was established by an act of the legislature on February 3, 1860. The South-Western Telegraph Company was one of the primary providers of telegraphy services in the southern Mississippi Valley and the Southwest and had many locations throughout that area. (Robert Harding and Alison Oswald, "Guide to the Western Union Telegraph Company Records," 4; Weekly Mississippian, February 8, 1860)
"A time when people vote in order to choose someone for a political or official job." (Cambridge Dictionary)

This subject tag includes references to various and unidentified state and local elections held within Mississippi. During the Civil War, most Mississippians supported secession and the Confederacy and therefore voted in favor of policies and for candidates dedicated to those causes. After the defeat of the Confederacy in 1865, President Andrew Johnson instituted a lenient Reconstruction policy that offered amnesty to individuals who took an oath of loyalty to the United States (with exceptions for certain upper-class southerners). This policy allowed many former Confederates to run for office shortly after the end of the war and pass legislation designed to limit the rights of freed African Americans, known as the Black Codes. Restrictions against black political rights led Republicans in the U.S. Congress to take a firmer hand in Mississippi’s Reconstruction and protect Black rights. Between 1867 and 1876, Republicans backed by federal soldiers struggled to ensure Black Mississippians had equal voting rights and could run for office.

Many white southern conservatives, however, used threats and violence to prevent Black Mississippians and white Republicans from voting, or influence the results of elections. These efforts reached a peak in 1874 under the “Mississippi Plan,” which began with a systematic effort to disenfranchise Black voters in Mississippi and evict African American and Republican office holders. As many as three hundred Black people were killed in Vicksburg in the racial violence. President Ulysses S. Grant sent federal troops to Vicksburg to enforce the law, but soldiers were unable to change the political climate within the state. White Democrats organized under the Mississippi Plan suppressed Black and Republican voters enough to dominate state elections in 1875 by 30,000 votes. Reconstruction ended in 1877 with white conservatives still in command of Mississippi’s state and local politics. (Wikipedia; Jason Phillips, "Reconstruction in Mississippi: 1865–1876," Mississippi History Now)

Mississippi held several elections in 1863 to fill various state, county, and local offices. Elected positions ranged from governor, to representatives in the Confederate House of Representatives, to state legislators, to county sheriffs, to probate clerks. These elections typically did not involve formal political parties, and candidates ran individual campaigns. However, some voters did support candidates along previous party affiliations (Whig versus Democrat). The 1863 elections revealed a trend of moderation away from the “fire-eating” secessionist extremism of 1861. Charles Clark, who had been opposed to secession in the 1850s, won Mississippi’s gubernatorial race with seventy percent of the vote that year, and voters elected former Whigs and previous opponents of secession to the Confederate Congress. (Wikipedia)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Pettus Collection. Telegram from Wiley Pope Harris in Columbus, Mississippi, asking the Mississippi Secretary of State C. A. Brougher to send statement as to the judges election.

div.fw: Telegram from Wiley Pope Harris to the Secretary of State Judah Philip Benjamin; November 9, 1863
div.p:
SOUTH-WESTERN TELEGRAPH COMPANY.
Columbus, Miss No. 9th 1863.

By Telegraph from Brandon 9th 1863.
To Secy of State
Send statement as to Judges election.
